151201253.review:
DDLC - the best visual novel in the last 6 years.
Still as engaging and charming as it was back then, with all those positive emotions and memories associated with it, never fading.
This game is about literature things, the meaning of poetry, philosophy and psychology of life and relationships; About those 4 wonderful girls who revealed themselves fully as bright and soulful characters for all VN lovers or just random players; About the mods for this game and their stories, as well as their creators, who contributed the vibrant love, closeness, new colors and inspiration to this whole community, who charge us to take a step forward and create something new for this place, too...
This VN was able to reveal some of my good qualities which have been useful to me through my life, and so... Thanks again to Dan Salvato and his team for their hard work in creating and for long supporting of this masterpiece!

150155908.review:
Doki Doki Literature club is not what it seems........

You are thrust into a virtual novel based off the plot of a high school anime: you are a student joining a literature club with the hopes of getting a bit closer to some of its members. The story and dialogue are well thought out and you will find yourself wanting to build relationships with the 4 girls: Sayori, Natsuki, Yuri, and Monika. You will make important choices and decisions that may or may not affect the future of the story. After a few different playthroughs, I can thoroughly recommend anyone who likes virtual novels to embark on the quest to join and meet new members of the literature club!

Disclaimer: The warnings for this game SHOULD be taken seriously. Proceed with caution! At the same time, it's just a romantic novel with a stereotypical story; WHAT COULD GO WRONG???

150151103.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club is unique and shocking gaming experience that was quite unlike any I've ever had; I'm not into dating sims or visual novels, but this game so much more than it appears on the surface.  It pulls you in with its visuals and characters, and just as you sink in to it's cutesy anime/manga/light novel vibes, IT GETS CRAZY.  

I'm not going to spoil any of the plot, but if you're easily triggered or sensitive to mental health issues and realistic portrayals of trauma, stress and toxic behavior - this game may not be for you.  However, if you are mature enough for this game, it delves into parts of society that are often too taboo to discuss and was a totally unique experience quite unlike any other game I've ever played (and I've been gaming since the 1980's). 

It's not all doom & gloom though, this game was clearly made by passionate people who took the game seriously; it never feels like they're punching down or making light of mental disorders, but shining a light on how they can affect anyone, even the most normal and unassuming people.  

The game was free originally, but I enjoyed it so much that I gladly paid for a copy now the DDLC Plus is available!  I can't wait to try the extra stuff and earn the achievements.  Make sure you play it all the way through...It's worth it!! (Trust me, you've NEVER played anything like Doki Doki Literature Club before)!!

I also really appreciated the interaction with the game files, which change dynamically as the game progresses. A unique experience that I highly recommend!

149884004.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club is Brilliant in a ... horrifyingly physiologically way if you can make sense of that it doesn't use jump scares it uses unconventional nature? within a visual novel type style and a "dating... simulator" ive played hundreds of horror games and wasn't scared a bit basically a younger version of moist critical but this one this one was good this is a horror game you will think about for days, weeks, for me months for my friends YEARS (keep in mind ive only played this 2 months ago on itch.io replayed it on steam to revisit it) this game has brought me through he depths of hell and back. Please go play it 

I don't know how to picture this without spoiling anything and its best to go into it blindly but heres a quick rundown and to.. prepare you for this You the MC are in a high school and need to find a club due to your best friend Sayori and she brings you to the literature club which shes the vice president i believe with 3 other girls.

Monika: Different then the other girls most athletic and popular girl in the school and President of the club.

Yuri: Into books, very studious. Introverted and Loves horror books much more mature.

Natsuki: Into anime, happy-go-lucky, Likes animals, Cutesy shit.

The rest is up to you to figure out.

Great game made me cry even though i haven't cried to any movie or game before (excluding last of us)
100/10 A+++

Love,
Your Best Friend Mdawg

תראה איך אתה נראה, אבא שלך זה עובי מלך הסלן עם דוביגל יבן זונההה תראה איך אתה נראה יאפס, אתה בטח- שב בשקט שאני מדבר!!!!! אתה בטח נראה בן זונה, אתה הילד המפגר הזה שבים, אתה הילד הזה שבא בים עם המקל של הפירולו ומרים את המדוזה, אא אני גיבור הים, לךךך תשן על ספסלים אמאשלך מקרצפת רצפות, אתה לא מפחיד כאן אף אחדדד. מיייי אתה בכלל, מי אתה בכלל?! מי אתה תגיד, מה יראש ביצה, יהומו מה? מהה??אתה לא מסוגל מהההה?!???! כוסעכטק ערס על הבוקר, צריך לצעוק פה על ילד שקטן ממני ב25 שנים אני יודע כמה?? כוסעכטק ערס עם הילדים המעצבנים האלה, גם כן הוא, אתה יודע מי זה, זה הילד הזה שבא חושב הוא מלך.כוס של האמאשלך יראש ונטילטור אל תצא עלי בחיים למה אני יזיין אותך. בואאאא תזיין את הכוס הדודה, אני יפתח את המנעול שרק תוכל להכנס, יא 20 סנטים אתה נכנס עם היד, רגל, כל הגוף היא בכלל לא מרגישה אותך יא ילד מפגר, מי אתה בכלל יא מנסטרי, כוס של הדודה שלך יא סתום יראש צבע עפרון יבן זונה יא ראש מגנזיום כוס של האמאשך . אתה יודע מה מתאים לך? פוסטר "שלום כיתה א", מי אתה תראה איך אתה מקלל יבן זונה, אני מתחיל עם לירון ואיתך ועם הכוס של אחותך, בוא כולכם עליי בוא, מי אתה בכלל יהומו מפגר יש לך קלפים של פוקימון יא מזדיין בתחת , אתה תהייה בשקט שאני מדבר, אתה תהיה בשקטטטט אתה אל תצעקקק, אתה תהיה בשקט פה תקשיב לי טוב, תקשיב לי טוב יבן זונה אתה והחבר שלך, אתה יודע מה אני עושה לכם?? שב בשקט רגע יא ילד מפגר תקשיבבב, אמא שלך זונה אמא שלך זונה תקשיב טוב, אדון מיינסטרים היקר, השעה 12 ורבע בבוקר, הדבר שאני מציע לך לעשות, אני יתן לך אחי מצלמה, לך תעשה דשא בסקופ, אני יתן לך סיליקון לך תתקן חלונות באייסי, אתה רוצה אני יסדר לך עבודה של 96 תתדלק את הטיל, מי ילך יבן זונה אבא שלך רצח את רבין ילא מתבייש, אבא שלך הורס קופסאות בפורט ימזדיין, מה קשור דוחות מה קשור יילד קטן, יא ילד מפגר אני יכול להיות אבא שלך ואח שלך והאמא שלך, מה אתה יכול להגיד מה?? מה אתה יכול להגיד, חסר חיים?? מה??, אני לא מבין, מה אתה?? בואנה יבן זונה אתה תקשיב עכשיו לפני שאני עולה על הבמה נותן לך בראש שובר את הביצה אתה תשב בשקט, גיבור בים רץ עם מקל פירולו ומדוזה, אתה אסור לך להכנס למים העמוקים על מה אתה מדבר ישך תחתון משולש אמא שך אתיופית יבן זונה אמא שך בגבס אבל אתה יודע מה אמא שלי לא?? > Think, "Oh, a cute dating sim, this should be fun!"
> Start playing
> Meet the "unique" characters
> Realize they're about as deep as a kiddie pool
> Spend hours clicking through dialogue drier than a desert in a drought
> "Poetry" minigame makes me question my life choices and sanity
> Suddenly, the game takes a dark turn
> Supposed to be scary
> More like a fluffy bunny attempting a Hannibal Lecter impression
> Everyone loses their minds over Monika
> Apparently, she's cute for being a psychopath
> Facepalm.exe
> Fanbase worships her and the other characters' deaths
> Feel like I'm in a parallel universe where insanity is a virtue
> Game tries to be deep and edgy
> Ends up as deep as a kiddie pool
> In the end, it's just a pretentious, overhyped mess
> MFW I realize I wasted my time, and my brain cells are sending me eviction notices 🙄🚫😂
[/b]

Stay safe and be cautious if you decide to play this game, as it contains deeply distressing content.

"Doki Doki Literature Club," or as I like to call it, "Doki Doki Literature Dumpster Fire," is a game that manages to combine the worst elements of both the dating simulator and horror genres into a truly mind-boggling mess. It's like trying to enjoy a gourmet meal made of Play-Doh and stale cheese. 😒🧀

The characters in this game are as captivating as watching paint dry in a room with no windows. The protagonist is about as interesting as a wet cardboard box, and the supporting cast of "cute" girls are about as one-dimensional as characters can get. You've got the tsundere, the yandere, and the other -dere characters, all thrown together in a blender of tired clichés. It's like the game's developers went to the "Anime Character Stereotype Emporium" and just grabbed a handful of characters off the shelf. 😑📦

The gameplay is equally uninspired. You spend most of your time clicking through endless lines of repetitive dialogue that make you feel like you're stuck in a never-ending loop of bad teenage poetry. And don't even get me started on the "poetry" minigame, which is about as much fun as watching paint dry in slow motion. 🙄🎨

As for the game's horror elements, it's like trying to be terrified by a fluffy bunny in a tutu. It attempts to be edgy and disturbing, but it falls flat and comes off as laughable and over-the-top. The game's attempts at psychological horror are about as effective as a kids' magician performing a lame card trick. 🐰🎩

And then there's the fanbase's obsession with trying to make Monika, the supposed "antagonist," appear sympathetic and innocent. The term "simp-pathetic" doesn't even begin to cover the level of distortion they engage in. Monika is not some misunderstood angel trapped in a digital hell; she's a malevolent force who manipulates, torments, and even abuses the other characters in ways that can be disturbing. The fanbase's glorification of her and the characters' deaths is nothing short of disconcerting, making me feel sick and depressed at the depths to which fandom obsession can sink. 😩😡

In the end, "Doki Doki Literature Club" is a trainwreck that combines bad writing, shock value, and a fanbase that seems determined to embrace the worst aspects of the game. It's not clever, it's not deep, it's just a cringe-worthy spectacle that tries too hard to be something it's not. 😒🤯😤

[I]
[Scene: A grand celestial court with God, played by Morgan Freeman, sitting at the head. The Devil from Bedazzled, portrayed by Elizabeth Hurley, the Devil from Little Nicky, and the Devil from Reaper, played by Ray Wise, are standing before Him.]

God: [In a booming yet amused voice] Well, well, well, look who we have here. The devilish trio.

Devil from Bedazzled: [Smirking] Oh, hello, darling. What brings you to our humble abode today?

Devil from Little Nicky: [Chuckling] Yeah, what's got your halo in a twist, old man?

Devil from Reaper: [Slyly] Always a pleasure to see you, big guy. What's the occasion?

God: [Pointing a celestial remote at a holographic screen showing DDLC gameplay] I'll tell you what the occasion is. This... thing. [Points to the screen, revealing scenes from Doki Doki Literature Club]

Devil from Bedazzled: [Looking at the screen with raised eyebrows] Oh, my. That's a tad... grim for my taste.

Devil from Little Nicky: [Scratching his head] Not my style either, Big G. Too much drama, not enough fire and brimstone.

Devil from Reaper: [Nervously adjusting his tie] Uh, yeah, that's not really our brand of evil, you know?

God: [Frowning] Then what in the heavens is this? What kind of sick and twisted mind concocts a game that makes people question their sanity?

Devil from Bedazzled: [With a dismissive wave] Oh, come on, darling. We may be devils, but we're not that diabolical. That's some next-level stuff.

Devil from Little Nicky: [Raising his hands defensively] Yeah, seriously, God. I may be mischievous, but I'm not into mind games like that.

Devil from Reaper: [Nervously chuckling] Yeah, I prefer my evil a bit more... hands-on, you know what I mean?

God: [Sighing] Well, I suppose you're right. [Pauses, tapping His chin thoughtfully] But then who could be responsible for this monstrosity?

[The three devils exchange puzzled glances as God continues to ponder the source of the game's creation.] [/i]

[b]PROS:[/b]

- Catchy music and beautifully detailed scenery and characters.
- Interesting use of Ren'Py scripting creates an immersive story experience.
- I enjoyed the creative writings shared by the NPCs in the club, which helped convey their inner personalities and emotional states.

[b]CONS:[/b]

- Story is a little short, wish there was more time to get to know the characters in-depth.
- Psychological trauma
- Not as much literature as I had hoped for.  It would be nice if there was more discussion about books (real or imaginary) in the club.

149363662.review:
this game isn't called a psychological horror for no reason. i don't think it's the jumpscares that make the horror, it's the ambience, and the circumstances that these girls have found themselves in.
i feel bad for all of them, including monika. i mean, imagine finding out that your entire existence is a lie. there's so much existentialism and doubting in reality and philosophy here. reading monika's poems evokes a sense of wandering, longing, confusion, and fear.
oh yeah, the poems. i love how they all have their own styles, their own symbolism. they all have different (yet similar) things they want to talk about and evoke in their writing. it's expressed beautifully, i believe. take for example natsuki's poems. they are blunt, short, sweet, and kind of simple in a sense of imagery. however, her writing is both about reading between the lines and provoking thought, as well as taking the words at face-value.
it is inevitable that some people in a fanbase may misunderstand what the game is trying to say, and i will not claim that i am not one of those people, because i very well may be. it is just a shame, to me, that this game was reduced to its gore, violence, and outlandish nature, one of the characters made out to be more evil and sinister than she actually is, when there is so much more. there are so many analogies of mental health and commentary on how the world treats those who are not doing well mentally, as well as how those on the outside looking in can put so much importance into something that ends up being... not worth it.
i don't know. but i love this game. i ask that, even if you are not a fan of visual novels, you at least play this once through.

After playing this game for 8 hours, I feel like I'm gonna need days of therapy. And after hearing Monika's monologue for half an hour I kinda want to kms.
Haha jokes aside, I'd like to write a serious review about this visual novel.
One of the keys to this vn's success is how they innovate and break the boundaries. Not many visual novels break the fourth wall that well. Not many visual novels manipulates psychological horror the way this vn does.  Not many visual novels play with the plot like this one. Not many vn find the right ballance between laugh, fear, awkwards moments and what the heck just happened moments.
This is one of the best visual novels I've played. It's really something else.

148308518.review:
Quite honestly? Genuinely overrated.
They say that short experiences are best, but this just leaves this VN, in my opinion, shallow and lacking in depth.
Unfortunately for DDLC, it banks too much on the "self aware" and "Psychological Horror" aspect, which, if you take that away, youre left with cardboard cutouts of characters.

Am I biased due to my experiences with longer Visual Novels? Sure, but that doesnt take away from the fact that due to the fact that it is as short as it is, it just isnt very good.

This isnt to say that small studios are bad at making Visual Novels, of course not. One must remember that, for example, Type Moon, when they released the original Tsukihime in the year 2000 were not even a proper company, yet it is regarded as one of the finest Visual Novels ever made (yes it has aged quite a bit, its a product of its time after all) 

But I dont want to make a review where I lambast a VN for daring to exist, the Music is pretty alright, not exactly my style, but it isnt bad, the Visuals are good though, and I apologize for making kind of the same point again, the character designs are not exactly my style.
The story, again, is the only point where it falls flat in my opinion (The one area a VN shouldnt fall flat in) but I already brought that point across before.

In summary, if you already read a few Visual Novels before, DDLC probably isnt for you.

148027263.review:
My experience with Doki Doki Literature Club was a mix of admiration and disappointment. Honestly hearing all the praise this game gets, after finishing it I feel like I'm in bizarro world, because I just come out feeling like the game is overhyped. On the positive side the game boasts a polished presentation with a captivating art style and design choices. The creative concept and eerie glitch effects scattered throughout the later half of the game give it a unique vibe overall. However, it fell short in terms of character development and overall writing quality. And when I go into a "visual novel" style game, i'm fully expecting the writing to be the strongest aspect, not the weakest. The writing and plot setup just fall completely flat and don't provide the player enough motivation to genuinely care about the tragic events that unfold, especially since the players actions don't influence the outcome. 

[spoiler]Additionally, the character Monika was oddly absent for much of the story, leaving her character underexplored and underdeveloped. Just to emerge as the main antagonist and turn into a weird 2D anime girl deadpool who breaks the fourth wall with every conversation.[/spoiler]

Overall I have to give the game a positive review just on the basis it's free. Likely would be a negative review otherwise. If you haven't played the game its worth the couple hour experience just to see if its your cup of tea. But if you get an hour or two in and feel completely bored by the mediocre slice of life dialogue, don't feel bad if you put the game down early. You won't be missing much.

147862258.review:
Very interesting game, I recommend it to everyone. From the very beginning, there is a plot in which you simply watch the development of its events. From the first act - the usual plot; the second act - the development of events, where the character who could normally make the game disappears. But because of his absence, everything does not go as it should, and because of this, the script breaks, and everything goes wrong. Therefore, the development of events is constantly distorted, which makes everything go terribly (black dialogue, distortions/terrible textures of characters, flipping the camera, slightly spoiling the music, etc.). And this is just my opinion, why this happens in the second act. Act 3 - in fact, everything is encrypted here, no changes in the files give anything. I tried to place a save from another act - nothing happens. Even the presence of files of all characters does not give anything. Or maybe I was so lucky that nothing happened to me.

Let's move on to the conclusion. Before finally finishing the game (at the time of writing the review, I haven't yet finished, and I will explain this), of course, I was interested in completing the game to a good ending. In each new game (1st act), you have to play with one character, constantly write a poem for him, or write a poem in the style of a certain user. In the second act it is like this, either it works once, the very first choice of the style of the poem, or all the poems here are randomly generated, only the factor of who I decided to write for has an effect, and the poem itself is randomly generated in the end.

Now let's write why I'm not writing a review when I haven't finished playing the game completely. As I played through the game for a good ending, I became interested in experimenting with what if you choose other choices when you walk, for example, in the same line as the character. There is another interesting factor here if you play multi-line. That is, you write poems not only for one character. I hope that during the development of the game they anticipated this, and that they did something interesting there.

And let me allocate a separate paragraph for coding... Nothing to say here. One of the reasons is that I am not a very professional programmer. Yes, there are cases when non-professional programmers are able to somehow influence the game through game files. From restarting the game, deleting one file, managing your saves, and deleting/adding character files in the [i]characters[/i] folder. All of this is undoubtedly interesting, but talking and one more theorizing will be too much, and also because I am not very good at it.

147775328.review:
Very interesting game. Immediately gives off that cute anime vibe with the bright, flashy, pink menu screen and happy (earworm-inducing) soundtrack, but don't let it fool you: the story and characters are actually pretty deep. The story is pretty captivating and interesting like other great games like this. I found the first unintentional 4th wall break kinda funny and unexpected; I like the inclusion of actual japanese words like, doki-doki (essentially pounding heartbeat) and kawaii (cute) in the poem minigame.

I'd definitely recommend it to those who like text-based visual novels like this and it's definitely best to go in blind without Googling anything on the first run so you don't ruin any surprises.

While the game is in fact great just like any good visual novel game, it does take a very dark and depressing turn (it is psychological horror, after all) and I'll say it could take maybe a day or two to get over the depressing part in the first playthrough if you really empathize with or relate to the emotions of the characters assuming you're a mature, mentally stable adult (not a child), but I was de-sensitized to it the second time around when going for the better ending so it wasn't as bad then.

Another neat thing that I didn't notice the first time around was the little things that pop up in the game's file directory later in the game, so it's a good idea to keep the directory open and refresh the window from time to time while playing to you don't miss anything.

P.S: IF. U. ARE. EASILY. DISTURBED. DO. NOT. TOUCH. THIS. OR. U. WILL. NEED. THE. THERAPY

[spoiler]Gives me portal flashbacks like: the female antagonist is watching u at all times, she has the ability to reshape and influence the environment around u, there's some form of cake, she's evil, you have to face her alone in a room at the end, she sings you a song during the credits, and the character that was your friend throughout the game becomes evil after the antagonist is defeated (if u get the normal DDLC ending)[/spoiler]

147059695.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. 146809259.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club, a seemingly innocent visual novel available for free on Steam, manages to subvert expectations and deliver an experience that is both charming and deeply unsettling. It's a game that boldly experiments with the conventions of the genre, leaving players with a mix of emotions.

On the positive side, Doki Doki Literature Club boasts well-crafted character development and genuinely engaging interactions with the members of the literature club. The writing is often witty and heartfelt, making it easy to connect with the characters on a personal level. The game's subtle nods to literature and the creative inclusion of poems add depth to the storytelling. The way it delves into sensitive themes, such as mental health and the consequences of one's actions, is commendable, encouraging players to reflect on these subjects long after the game is over. Moreover, the incorporation of horror elements, despite its initial appearance as a dating sim, provides a unique and memorable twist that sets it apart from traditional visual novels.

However, the game's strengths are not without their caveats. The slow start may deter some players, as it takes a while for the true nature of the narrative to reveal itself. Additionally, the content can be genuinely unsettling and disturbing, which may not be suitable for all audiences. While its unconventional approach is a refreshing departure from the norm, it can also be polarising, leaving some players perplexed or unsatisfied.

In summary, Doki Doki Literature Club is an ambitious and innovative take on the visual novel genre. Its strong character development, clever writing, and thought-provoking themes are praiseworthy, as is its ability to create a sense of unease. However, its slow start and potentially disturbing content may not appeal to everyone. If you're willing to embark on a rollercoaster of emotions and appreciate games that challenge conventions, Doki Doki Literature Club offers a memorable and thought-provoking journey into the mindscape of visual novels.

146433917.review:
[Warning. Small spoilers up ahead, mostly on the games mid-game aspects.]






I can not express how much I love this game.

DDLC [Doki Doki Literature Club] is a wonderful game entirely.

Before I had this game, this was always known to me to be terrifying. But, upon playing it, I realized something. This game is much more than just cutesy little Anime girls dying. It's just such a good game. The characters, the dark twist's and turns, it's a wonderful experience. At the time of writing, it's only been 2.6 hours. But this game seriously is amazing.

The 4 Doki girls, all hold amazing lore. Granted, it isn't a lot, but it's something that someone; like me; can enjoy massively. 

I was.. a solid 7 or 8 years old when this game came out. After watching the entire game, I was hooked on the horror and the scenes of murder. It was just a really cool look to me. I watched countless mods, and eventually grew out of them when I was a bit older. But when me and my friend happened to be looking through games, I stumbled upon DDLC again. I was tempted to try it, and I thought I really should. Best choice of my fucking life.

In conclusion: 10/10. Even higher if I could!

[EDIT:]

146370367.review: This game is a horror game, it can be really disturbing to people, so before playing maybe read the warnings online, though that would definitely be spoilers for the game. That being said, you also might wanna play this before playing ddlc plus, ddlc plus just has new stories and a lot more secrets, but if you don't know if you'll like the game first, I would suggest playing this to start with. Okay for actual review: The CGs are beautiful, the OST is beautiful, the characters are unique (even though they are stereotypical anime girls), the story is something that instantly sets this game aside from normal visual novel or anime games, actually, different from ANY game I've seen, I have never seen a game do what this game has, at least before its release. It is truly an experience, you can tell a lot of love and care was put into it. The amount of secrets that there are within the game, the amount of decoding [spoiler] and file changes, secrets within the files, having to change literal character files to find hidden secrets, [/spoiler] it's all so unique and I love it. I really hope to see more from Team Salvato, especially with all the lore there seems to be. I'm really looking forward to whatever comes next! (if anything at all, if not, that's okay too, I still love this game the way it is)

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

145950269.review: A friend introduced me to this game in college, and that first blind play-through I was beyond shocked the entire way through. Flash forward to today where I had the strange urge to replay this after several years, and the game is still as unusual as ever but in a good way. Yes, this game can be quite dark (please read for triggers in the game description as there are many!!!), but it's such a unique spin on the romantic sim games that its worth a play-through at least once. There are so many hidden secrets in this game, many of which are randomly occurring, and there are different characters to interact with that can change what cut scenes you may get. Despite it being very unusual, I would still recommend this game if you can stomach the darker tone that comes in halfway through the game and enjoy being taken for a wild ride. (Go in blind if you can; it really makes the experience much more interesting!)

145442706.review:
Let's be honest here - you either are a weeb, consuming anything Anime, or you like horror games and got the game recommended to you by a friend or something, and upon asking them why in god's name are they asking you to play a Visual-Novel waifu game, they responded with "Trust me, bro".

Seriously now, Doki Doki looks and starts innocent. You go through the game and perhaps feel a little cringe at the start, hoping your parents don't come into your room, but the game will make a sudden turn at some point and you realise how messed up it is - that's when you'll understand why you had the game suggested to you.
I'm not usually a consumer of Visual-Novels myself but I actually enjoyed Doki Doki a lot. The game itself was fun enough for me, maybe a little cheap at times but I think the scares are pretty well done here, it was a nice mixture of uneasy and anxiety mixed together with some seriously messed up stuff and dark humour as well as the breaking of the 4th wall - that was really well done here.
The music here was actually pretty alright too, some catchy, silly tunes playing in the background, at times sped up as to induce anxiety in certain situations, later to be completely distorted during the more messed up parts.

I was pretty happy with what Doki Doki was as is, until I learned of the existence of mods.
Namely "Blue Skies", "Fallen Angel" as well as "Exit Music" caught my attention. It's really important to remember to treat the main game as well as all 3 mods separately when playing them all - they're all [b] very [/b] different characters in each!
I can wholeheartedly recommend these 3 mods for their amazing stories and effort, character creation, character building as well as music! Playing them was amazing, finding myself actually liking and caring for the characters and learning about them.
For a change, it no longer was about horror anymore, but a bit of a mixture of different things, still scary in a way, still possibly heartbreaking, but also heartwarming in some cases. I enjoyed each of the mods for different reasons, but they're all amazing, seriously - check them out!

145225132.review:
Mood spoilers ahead. I absolutely recommend that you play this game blindly, this is one of the most memorable games I've ever played.

[spoiler]Doki Doki Literature Clubs' ending still gives me this feeling of sadness/remorse for the end of the game, this feeling that there was a happy place that existed that is just gone now where nothing can be done about it, a feeling I'm sure many of us have experienced IRL. The song at the end[/spoiler] and the themes it explores impact me personally, and how it builds up to deliver this message is absolutely wonderfully well crafted. I will always remember this game and hope someday I can introduce it to a friend so they can play through it blindly like I did. I wrote this review because the game came up in my thoughts so I clicked on a playthrough and watched some of the most memorable parts, which made me remember how much it impacted me when I first played it, and realize that it still impacts me in the same way today. I don't like visual novels, I don't really like anime, and I feel still that this is an experience that I can come back to and thoroughly enjoy.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my daughter, who is 16 now. My daughter got this game from her uncle, so she installed it on her computer and she started playing. By the end of the week she had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my daughter, as she is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside her. I loaded into the game and joined my lobby, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my daughter for help so she hosted a game for me. We played a lot together, I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my daughter since my wife had died. Thanks to this game this brought me and my daughter closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my daughter many happy memories.

Thank you Doki Doki Literature Club.

144918042.review:
The warnings under-fucking-stated how fucked up this game is.
Thoroughly.
Here's the thing - I'm literally the guy in the first play-through. I was legit insulted how well this game represents me.

Let's stray off for a moment.
For about 3 months a dated this girl who was essentially Sayori. The only difference is that she had a pixie cut.
Real life Sayori.
For those 3 months I was essentially dating Sayori.
I was in heaven.
What happened in the game happened irl too.
Sure, she wanted to try weed and absinthe. Again, minor distractions. The game happened IRL 1:1.
If you read some Dostoevsky, when something truly happy happens, usually, the guy finding the love of his life, he describes it as "it was as if gold was snowing instead of snow." [translated]
I got it. I really understood it. Frankly, it was an understatement.

Unearthing those memories was hard. Painful and joyous at the same time.
Then, a certain... event... happened.
With my ex, it was less painful than in DDLC, but painful nonetheless. Only slightly less painful.
DDLC cut the breaks and went full throttle.
I had to end the stream early.
I had nightmares about my ex doing the same "event" for 3 days.

The warnings at the start of the game are legit.
Second and third playthroughs had no effect. They were fucked up, but not as fucked up as the first playthrough.
BE VERY FUCKING CAREFUL ABOUT YOUR MENTAL STATE!
